newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates, spots end mixed.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates, spots end mixed.

text.p: Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai closed mixed on Wednesday, with falling domestic stock markets in Shanghai and Shenzhen dampening sentiment on the repo market, traders said.
The annual rate for the most active seven-day contracts closed down at 10.00 percent from 11.00 percent on Tuesday.
Turnover fell to nearly 5.9 million lots from 6.34 million. One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
"The repo market has been less active since late last week when the A markets began to fall," said a trader. "Its short-term trend will continue to be linked to the A market performance."
Contracts on the T-bill spot market in Shanghai ended mixed in slow trading, with most investors taking a wait-and-see attitude, waiting for a new listing later this month, traders said.
The most active 10-year bond that matures in June 2006 fell slightly to 122.70 yuan from 122.76 yuan.
Combined volume of the eight-contract market rose slightly to 1.20 million lots from 919,228 lots.
China's first seven-year bond is now being issued and will be listed on the market on November 21. Traders said its movement after the listing would affect prices of existing contracts.
